column1: 1;6418851215;"EZreviwws";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id3742366";"2.1.9";3;"Good tool for a virtual world";"This is a good tool to have in today‚Äôs virtual world where kids are now attending classes online via zoom and Google and other platforms and have access to computers and Internet connected devices 24/7. For working parents and those who can‚Äôt sit next to their kids 24/7
column2: it‚Äôs nice to have a tool that allows one to filter content and limit access to non-educational sites such as games and video/television (especially during class time) and to enforce off-screen and bed times.

column1: The issues I have with this app arise when there is need for kids to access content that has been filtered or access a computer beyond an allowed time frame. It takes a little research and tinkering to figure out why a certain application or webpage is being blocked. For example
column2: the app will notify if kids have exceeded screen time parameters
column3: but it does not notify if content is being blocked because of bedtime or off time access parameters. (Sometimes more than one blocking parameter is causative.) The app will alert kids if content is being filtered
column4: but it takes a real sleuth to figure out what filter parameter is being triggered. When I don‚Äôt have the time to play Sherlock Holmes and dig through history
column5: it‚Äôs just easier to temporarily disable everything
column6: which defeats the purpose of having this app.

column1: In conclusion
column2: I wish the app would tell me specifically what and why something is being blocked and easily allow me to override the block as needed.";"2020-09-11T11:39:14-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=1037062934&type=Purple%20Software";"1037062934";251;"en";"POSITIVE"

column1: 2;5831261060;"toddrub";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id8901845";"2.1.8";2;"Latest Circle Bedtime Server Crash leaves Devices invisible.";"We have had Circle for less than four months
column2: and it was used in conjunction with our new Netgear routerÔøº model R7960 Tri-Band. The router is amazing and the Netgear NightHawk software for iOS is terrific.Ôøº However the Circle app has been touch and go ever since we originally set it up. Then things got incredibly worse with the latest Circle bedtime sever crash. All settings were backed up
column3: but upon deleting the app (during troubleshooting phase) it takes the back up with it. Upon new install and setup
column4: no devices can be seen.Ôøº Chat support was mediocre. Another Circle app reinstall with the Nighthawk software proved to be futile as well. Then the final straw was a fourth time set up saving one profile locked the screen and upon re-opening of Circle app started the process all over again from the beginning. Bottom line is that this particular software won‚Äôt even recognize any one of the 12 to 15 devices in our WiFi network even though all devices work seemlessly with the very robust Netgear WiFi router. The Circle concept and collaboration with Disney and Netgear is admirable. Our experience. Not so much. Subscription canceled today. :(";"2020-04-18T14:00:09-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=1037062934&type=Purple%20Software";"1037062934";198;"en";"POSITIVE"

column1: 15;6935329197;"anwallen";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id26959616";"2.1.11";1;"Currently useless against a tech savvy 11 year old";"The master pin rarely changes (I think only when a new admin device is added). So
column2: if you child ever gets hold of your phone
column3: he can note the master pin and add himself as an admin (or manager or whatever).

column1: You do get a notification
column2: but no ability to block  the new managing device.

column1: Once a device has been added as a manager it appears there is no way to deny it management rights.
To make matters worse
column2: you can set a pin in the app
column3: but you only need to enter the pin on a cold start of the app
column4: so if you change a permission and then let the child use your phone for something else
column5: they are able to access the app and master pin without knowing the app pin.

column1: There are a few changes I would make to secure the app better:
+ The app pin should be required every time you open the app
column2: even if you just go to the Home Screen for a second.

column1: + If there is one or more existing managers
column2: at least one should have to approve any new mangers.

column1: + The master pin should change more frequently. It should probably change every time you view it.
+ You should be able to kick out a manager.
+ If we can‚Äôt get a pre-approval system for new managers
column2: existing managers should be able to block new manager requests from specific devices or groups.   It seems crazy that a device with ‚Äúteen‚Äù permissions can become a manager.";"2021-01-30T23:36:25-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=1037062934&type=Purple%20Software";"1037062934";257;"en";"NEGATIVE"

column1: 20;4655112474;"one sad dad";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id85644965";"2.1.3";1;"Short changed";"We have used circle in our home for almost two years. It took a while to get things set up and running for each profile. We had to tweak the rules several times but we eventually got things running smoothly. About a month ago
column2: we had to replace our WiFi router. We shopped for one that was circle compatible. We thought this was a good idea. When everything got set up
column3: all of the features that we knew and loved from circle we now a subscription based feature. It became nothing more than a brick to us at that point. We can no longer set bed times

column1: 22;7341682516;"A Caveman";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id102097849";"2.1.12";1;"What this app did is SO WRONG.";"Like many other parents
column2: I bought a Nighthawk router largely because it came with this software and it delivered some useful features to set time limits
column3: set bedtimes
column4: etc.

column1: And while the app has always encouraged users to subscribe to a premium set of features
column2: it never changed the basic set of features that were initially provided. Until now.

column1: Recently and without warning
column2: most of the basic features of this app have been moved behind a ‚Äúpremium subscription‚Äù requirement.

column1: They are no longer honoring the advertising claims that were listed on the packaging of their very expensive router at the time of purchase.
Think about what this means...
* Every 5-star review praising this app is now deceiving.
* Even the screenshots are now deceptive
column2: showing features that were once available to the purchasers of their router without subscription
column3: that have now been removed unless you continue to pay.

column1: * Parents who purchased the Nighthawk router specifically in order to gain access to this type of control have had the rug pulled out from beneath them unless they continue to pay.
It is like taking the control you once had
column2: and holding it hostage. You want it back? Pay up.";"2021-05-15T05:49:23-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=1037062934&type=Purple%20Software";"1037062934";200;"en";"POSITIVE"

column1: 24;6936192411;"Uncle Festah";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id29891067";"2.1.11";1;"Interrupts internet with Netgear routers";"Update: if I could lower this review based on developer response I would. They sent me to a standard troubleshooting guide that totally fails to acknowledge a problem on their end and instead suggests a whole bunch of other things besides Circle are the problem.

Circle: get it together and own this problem. The internet is riddled with people reporting the same problem and getting no support from you or Netgear. I've disabled Circle and requested a refund on my subscription and I'm sure more Netgear Orbi customers will be doing the same.
Beware before you buy. Google ""Orbi Circle Interrupt"" and review the comments.
You will see that neither Netgear nor Circle will take responsibility for problems with this service.

It caused periodic disconnect of all connected devices for months until I disabled it. If you work from home and spend time in web conferences or use VoIP audio you can imagine how disruptive this is.
I asked Apple for a subscription refund which they denied. There's basically no accountability here for a product that does not work.
If not for these fatal connection problems
column2: the Circle product is actually quite good and would get 4 or 5 stars on its merits.";"2021-01-31T04:47:00-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=1037062934&type=Purple%20Software";"1037062934";203;"en";"NEGATIVE"

36;4959546718;"anon1122345";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id273039010";"2.1.6";5;"Works very well";"Yes it takes time to setup.  This is not a set it and forget it type of service just like your kids aren‚Äôt all the same.  The internet is a big place and this thing can be adapted.
It is very customizable.  Not perfect.  It‚Äôs nice that there are so many profiles.

Mine is setup to give unknown devices almost no ability to go anywhere until I can figure out what it is.  This keeps the kids from bringing in new devices and getting into trouble. It also is an additional layer of security.
This thing can also be used to block trackers with a bit of effort.  History is certainly not exhaustive as the average website brings in content from many sources.
VPN blocking is also not exhaustive.  Those can be hard to spot.  One way is to visit websites and see what they are.

I like the various reviews from kids on here that hate it.  Says something about the product.";"2019-10-17T02:43:51-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=1037062934&type=Purple%20Software";"1037062934";163;"en";"NEGATIVE"

column1: Prior to the premium service going down
column2: this has been exactly what we were looking for. Reading the reviews from teenagers who are angry it exists is proof it works. We have a NetGear router that came with Circle integration.  Our speed has not been impacted in the slightest. Our oldest son is a gamer and he does not experience any lag. We ran speed tests between our current and old router
column3: and even with Circle
column4: the new router is actually faster (routers were fairly similar
column5: we upgraded for Circle). We discussed the limits we were imposing with our kids when we set it up (bedtimes
column6: age appropriate content filter
column7: etc.). The only times our kids even know we have circle is when they are doing something that is against our family rules. If they are following the rules
column8: it doesn‚Äôt have anything to block. When I was a teenager
column9: I thought I knew it all too and I didn‚Äôt agree with the rules my parents had for me
column11: I understand. If we don‚Äôt fight for our kids‚Äô purity and equip them to chose to be self-controlled
column12: this world will continue to devour their minds and creativity. In my opinion

column2: enabling the ability to manage sets of internet connected device and even monitor the website usage of certain sets on age based contents. You can monitor / filter types of websites
column3: control internet traffic to certain machines
column4: and even set up time limits (which i still have try the last one.)

column1: I am docking 2 stars because tracking and website filtering functions on the app abruptly stopped working. I went to their website and followed the initial steps to solve the problem and it didnt help - rebooting the router
column2: reinstalling the software
column3: etc. This didnt help. I contacted Circle‚Äôs customer service
column4: and they said they couldnt help and directed me to contact Netgear. Netgear is meticulous in th help they give
column5: but reaching them is hard and getting a case number in their systems is not quick. After 2 days of trial an error
column6: it was determined that the app was not compatible with the 0.98 firmware update that I was initally required to install upon setup of my router. (Beware this update
column7: RAX200 customers.) While this issue resta more with Netgear
column8: Circle should have known this too and notified customers automatically to keep them informed.

column1: So that‚Äôs why I docked 1 star. The second star I docked because of an experience that came up few days ago. I was having the same issue with website monitoring functionality going away. The app was acting up again
column2: and to be clear
column3: it was not tracking website history of machines I had setup to be observed and block online gaming from (on school days.) I went back to Circle‚Äôs  website to see if there was anything else I could do and did what i could at the time
column4: delete and reinstall the app as advised. That was yesterday
column5: and i had to wait this morning to follow up and reboot my router (because it was too busy on our WiFi for school
column6: work
column7: etc.) Upon rebooting
column8: and around 15 or so minutes
column9: the Circle App was working again. Becaue this second error happened
column10: I questioned the stability of the app and looked for more information on the website. I had found that the problems I had overlapped with the timesc that 2 updates happened for the app for bug fixes. That is frustrsting to hear and I find should‚Äôve been disclosed by the company. I feel Circle‚Äôs support system is lacking for the 1st Generation version of the app. Monitor updates when your app stops working. column1: The idea of circle is understandable
column2: as all parents should be concerned about what their children are doing online and should protect them from the horrible aspects that the internet can provide. But the fact that parents are spending their money on a network device that blocks out house WiFi (and cellular service) which they‚Äôre ALSO paying for is considered acceptable and convenient? I don‚Äôt see how this logically connects to every necessary part of the situation.

column1: I don‚Äôt see how I‚Äôll be able to contact my parents during a serious emergency while on the go if my internet is paused.
I don‚Äôt see how I‚Äôll be able to complete all my online school work if my parents have an ‚Äúall categories‚Äù limit set to 3 hours(I‚Äôve tried talking to them about that
column2: they just give me a 15 minute reward over and over which wastes all of our time. Lots of parents are passive-aggressive like mine).

column1: I don‚Äôt see how the whole mechanism is going to work
column2: if I‚Äôm spending my HARD EARNED money on cellular data
column3: and they‚Äôre just gonna spend THEIR money to block it out.

column1: Yeah
column2: the whole situation just wasn‚Äôt completely thought out by the developers. It is a brilliant idea to help protect children
column3: but the whole thing just isn‚Äôt very convenient for the whole party.

column1: Also
column2: circle just shouldn‚Äôt be necessary for kids older than the age of 16
column3: since they‚Äôll be a legal adult in just <2 years and they‚Äôll have to figure out how to manage their own screen time by themselves eventually.

column1: Parents
column2: if you‚Äôre planning on getting yourself this network-killing device
column3: please take a moment to look at yourself
column4: how your relationship with your children will be
column5: and if it‚Äôs going to be beneficial for EVERY part of their life(including online school!). Please be aware that your children will feel punished
column6: and will cause trust issues between you guys.

column1: If your children have some screen time problems right now
column2: I would deeply imply having a friendly conversation with them about it first before surprising them with a restriction right out of the blue. It‚Äôs like trying to quit smoking cold-turkey(not like they‚Äôre actually smoking
column3: just take it as a simile). As a teenager who has experience with parents who ghostly put restrictions on me whenever they want without telling me
column4: it‚Äôs a bit traumatizing.

column1: But
column2: if you‚Äôre a good parent and your kids know it
column3: and putting restrictions for them is necessary
column4: and all your limits you provide them are fully thought out

column1: OR
your children are just utterly psychotic and won‚Äôt get their eyes off a screen for less than 10 hours a day
column2: then go ahead and get Circle.

column1: Issues after setup:

369;1782359364;"Jjpettorino";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id101495968";"2.0.4";5;"A good device";"I am a parent of a teenager who spends entirely too much time on her devices.  I've tried other apps like kidslox (which was good but not great.  Circle is really easy to install and can give time limits to each app and or each category.  It is a nice tool for parents to use.  The MyCircle app also gives kids an app in which to monitor themselves.  I have only 2 complaints.  1) the monthly subscription of $5 beyond the $90 for the device and 2) for devices like the computer it only monitors the computer as a whole not each account on the computer.  So if a parent wants to use the computer they would be using the 'allotted' time given to the teenager.  True you can just change it to 'uncategorized' then change it back but that is not a smooth transition.  There are several areas which the company promises to improve but for my needs it works really well.  I do recommend this device/app for any parent that takes an active role in their child's online life.  This is in no way a parental replacement.  Don't listen to the naysayers of this device/app.  It is well worth the price although I would like to see a lower per month rate.";"2017-09-09T11:51:38-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=1037062934&type=Purple%20Software";"1037062934";214;"en";"POSITIVE"

382;3675364803;"PeanutRounder";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id6614122";"2.1.1";2;"Good..... but.....";"Been using this service for over a year and I really like it.   That said
column2: two major issues:

column1: 1). As soon  as your kid gets a Chromebook from school you loose 100% of any control this product provides.  Schools often use a VPN to ensure control over safe browsing.  When this happens not only can do you lose control over app content (which I understand based on how VPNs work) but you also lose the ability to control screen time.  The kids run out of time on the phone or tablet and then just use the Chromebook since it can‚Äôt be managed.   Unlimited time.

2). The kids are using all sorts off apps that aren‚Äôt identified in the filter.  When you go to ‚ÄúUsage‚Äù you‚Äôll find the bulk of the time is in the ‚Äúuncategorized‚Äù section with only an IP address to identify it.  A good example is Amino which is a community app with some really questionable content.  I‚Äôm sure most folks don‚Äôt know how to run a WHOIS command to track this down.  And even then it‚Äôs often uninformative.  Suggest Circle hires a couple folks to look at the top uncategorized sites and capture the content so we know the app that is associated to the IP address.  Many of these addresses now go to a company that builds/operates apps for their clients.   As such much of the information you would want from the app isn‚Äôt there.  As a parent you are left blind on the bulk of internet usage.    I hope the Product Manager for the app can prioritize something like this in the near term backlog.";"2019-01-20T15:37:43-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=1037062934&type=Purple%20Software";"1037062934";270;"en";"POSITIVE"

column1: My 2 teenage boys hate it (and their friends who stay over)!   I now have full control over when they can access the WiFi network in my house - control over each device and further control over which apps and websites.  I love that I get to limit the screen time and can do that for each individual app or website.    My personal favorite is bedtime - no more surfing late at night. I can also give time rewards for extra chores or extra ‚Äúsweetness‚Äù as my wife likes to say.

This is the first app review I have ever given - reflecting how strongly I feel about Circle.   This internet access control is more than I ever dreamed of.";"2019-01-04T20:22:00-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=1037062934&type=Purple%20Software";"1037062934";166;"en";"POSITIVE"

column1: 395;1520714067;"A Holmstrom";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id116746503";"1.4.2";5;"Love this product";"We use this at home and use the other app associated with this device

It does everything it's supposed to but there is a couple of tech issues with this app. The app will randomly restart as if you are setting it up new and requires you to make a new profile before you can see the current profiles already on the app. Then the other issue is with the circle go portion. It will say the device is deactivated when it is just connecting to a different wifi. Twice in the week we have had this the parent app says the vpn is disabled on the child device but when I check it is enabled. And only restarting the home router has fixed this issue. Please fix this and it will be perfect! These issues are minor compared to how well it works to filter

column1: 400;1617471492;"fam_circus";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id32383171";"1.6.2";5;"LOVE this device and app";"My husband and I LOVE this device and app. We have 3 kids and many devices in our house. We have profiles setup for each kid and even one for their shared items (computer

column1: 408;1373485916;"Gardengene";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id206852000";"1.2.0";5;"Exactly what we needed";"Setup was really fast and hasn't affected internet speed detectably

column1: 409;2222457004;"dmeix";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id266232316";"2.0.15";5;"Highly Recommend";"Circle has been a great addition in monitoring our kids internet usage. column2: if not if will slowly over time power off. This means it has to be in at an outlet. Step 1) find the location where it‚Äôs at.

column1: Step 2) the side with the plug in and light can be removed. Carefully using a flathead screwdriver or butter knife stick around the edge of the plastic slide down then up it should come lose.

Step 4) final step
column2: disconnect the cord from the circuit and then push both ends together. It will look like nothing ever happened.";"2019-07-06T21:55:42-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=1037062934&type=Purple%20Software";"1037062934";133;"en";"POSITIVE"

column2: lump them into categories
